articles.title: CUSTODY BATTLES
articles.text:
CUSTODY BATTLES
 
FOR a father who wants custody of his children, no amount of
McDonald's meals, Saturday afternoon movies or ice-creams in the park
can replace the ups and downs of being a full-time dad.



More than 30 per cent of marriages in Australia end in divorce. If a
father really wants custody of his children, he can fight for it. In
about 40 per cent of contested cases, he will win. Even if custody is
not contested, fathers end up with all the children in 18 to 21 per cent
of the cas ...

articles.title: IT'S ENOUGH TO MAKE YOU SICK
articles.text:
IT'S ENOUGH TO MAKE YOU SICK
 
ANY lingering belief that the unemployed live the life of Riley has
been shattered by recent studies that show those out of work and on low
incomes are sicker, physically and mentally, than other Australians.



Moreover, the unemployed get sicker the longer they are out of work
and the health of their immediate families is likely to suffer as well.
 
Last year the National Health Strategy (NHS), a Federal Government
inquiry  into health, released the most compreh ...

articles.title: UNHAPPILY EVER AFTER
articles.text:
UNHAPPILY EVER AFTER
 
Why a bad marriage may be better for your children than a good
divorce.



STAYING together for the sake of the kids. It's such an outdated
notion. What  was once seen as an act of sacrifice and moral strength is
today dismissed as misguided masochism. Bitter tight-lipped martyrs
living in hell with their equally miserable kids. Who needs it?
 
For the past two or three decades, we have embraced a different
approach to the issue of children and marriage breakdown: namely, ...

articles.title: Marginal Men
articles.text:
Marginal Men
 
They have no jobs, no money, no status - and no women. BETTINA ARNDT
examines new research that reveals a growing underclass of males with
little choice but to face life alone.



MARK Peel has fond memories of Elizabeth, the tough working-class
suburb in Adelaide where he spent his early years. A few years ago the
Monash University historian revisited the suburb to find out how the
working-class community was changing. Over many months he conducted
hundreds of interviews, not on ...

articles.title: CONFLICT AND POVERTY TAKE HIGHEST TOLL.
articles.text:
CONFLICT AND POVERTY TAKE HIGHEST TOLL.
 
POVERTY and conflict between parents are more to blame for children's suffering than the divorce itself, two Australian researchers have found.



More money should be spent on helping people to split amicably and start a new life than encourage them to stay together, they argue.
 
The report prepared for Britain's influential Joseph Rowntree Foundation claims if parents separated more amicably and without fighting, their children would be as well off a ...

articles.title: Single and sad
articles.text:
Single and sad A segment of society appears to have it all, but doesn't. NADINE WILLIAMS and SUSIE O'BRIEN report.

THEY'RE cashed up, career-driven and child free, yet working singles are among the unhappiest Australians. The Australian population has been divided by ``profilers'' into five categories to better understand our lives and issues that impact on our wellbeing, and if you're working and single it's likely you'll rank near the bottom of the happiness index.

The new social categories  ...

articles.title: Urban Poor Seek Richer Lives
articles.text:
Urban Poor Seek Richer Lives As high-income earners move to the cities, the poor are heading out of town and putting new pressure on rural communities. Bettina Arndt reports.

Coastal communities near Sydney are struggling to absorb large numbers of poor, welfare- dependent families moving out of the city seeking low rents. It is part of a nationwide shift in population, with high-income households moving into the cities and the poor moving out. This is leading to a high concentration of poor fa ...

articles.title: A PLACE ABUNDANCE
articles.text:
A PLACE ABUNDANCE
 
SYDNEY'S west: it is perceived by many to be nothing but an ugly
sprawl, a place where violence against women and children, youth gang
wars and street crime are commonplace. In popular imagery, its people
are unhealthy and overweight, wear tacky clothes, hoon around in
hotted-up cars, spend all their money on beer and poker machines, watch
rubbish on television and don't care about their environment.



To many people, western Sydney is a dumping ground for all of those
soci ...

articles.title: Abused and sick - Children of single mothers most at risk.
articles.text:
Abused and sick - Children of single mothers most at risk.
 
CHILDREN of single mothers are three times more likely to suffer physical, sexual or emotional abuse, according to an Australian Institute of Health and Welfare study.



But birth out of wedlock being a bastard - made little difference in today's society, most experts said.
 
There was little legal, cultural or social discrimination remaining now one in three Australian babies were born to unmarried parents.



Out of wedlock births  ...

articles.title: HOWE URGES SOCIETY NOT TO SHUN THE POOR
articles.text:
HOWE URGES SOCIETY NOT TO SHUN THE POOR
 
PERTH: Australians were increasingly treating poor families as social
outcasts, the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, said yesterday.



He criticised State governments for providing welfare housing in
isolated"ghetto-like" areas removed from mainstream city life and work
opportunities.
 
In a speech to a National Council of Women conference on marriage in
Perth, Mr Howe said the number of sole-parent families had doubled
between 1969 and 1985, mai ...

articles.title: WHY MARRIAGE MATTERS / Fault must be found for just family law.
articles.text:
WHY MARRIAGE MATTERS / Fault must be found for just family law.
 
By BARRY MALEY / STURT KRYGSMAN.



Married people enjoy higher levels of wellbeing than the unmarried, as do children living with their two married parents, writes Barry Maley, who says there's an argument for reintroducing fault to divorce
 
SOLE-PARENT families are now linked to a range of social problems. A variety of recent studies shows clear connections between these family circumstances and declining well-being of childre ...

articles.title: Health Study Finds Melbourne Residents In Good Shape
articles.text:
Health Study Finds Melbourne Residents In Good Shape
 
Melbourne is perhaps the healthiest Australian capital city. It has a
relatively low death rate, fewer low-birth-weight babies and a smaller
proportion of pensioners.



The explanation for Melbourne's robust state, according to the author
of a health study, lies in its relatively low proportion of socially
and economically  disadvantaged people.
 
`A Social Health Atlas of Australia' by Mr John Glover and Mr Tony
Woollacott, of the South A ...

articles.title: ARE THE WINDOWS LEVEL WITH FACES OF THE POOR?
articles.text:
ARE THE WINDOWS LEVEL WITH FACES OF THE POOR?
 
They lie, the men who tell us in a loud decisive tone,



That want is here a stranger and that misery's unknown;
 
... I wonder would the apathy of wealthy men endure



Were all their windows level with the faces of the Poor?



Faces in the Street, - Henry Lawson.



THERE is a common belief among the people of Sydney that the eastern
suburbs are the preserve of the wealthy. That the northern part of the

articles.title: 'HIPPIE KIDS' ARE DOING FINE
articles.text:
'HIPPIE KIDS' ARE DOING FINE
 
DOES living in a non-traditional family have a harmful effect on
children?The answer from research is a resounding "No" - contrary to
beliefs still held by many in our community. And this research is
reassuring, since an ever-increasing proportion of children in Australia
and throughout the world come from non-traditional families of various
lifestyles and configurations.



A major study has found that children who grow up in so-called hippie
families, for exampl ...

articles.title: Report Warns Of A City Divided In 2001
articles.text:
Report Warns Of A City Divided In 2001
 
By 2001, Sydney will be home to more than 4 million people and will
have cemented its position as a world city. But without government
action there will be an "offensive" disparity between the haves and
have-nots in a city economically and geographically divided, a new
report warns.



In the wake of Mr Carr's concern about Sydney's population growth, the
report  says Sydney will remain the biggest destination for immigrants,
and that it and  Melbourne a ...

articles.title: REGULAR SHORTS
articles.text:
REGULAR SHORTS
 
WILL POVERTY HELP SINGLE PARENTS?



SIR: I strongly disagree with Neil Paton (Letters, December 9) who
stated that is was a major mistake to give pensions to unmarried
mothers.
 
It is people like him, with a lack of understanding of the real causes
of poverty, who help contribute to the prejudices against the needy.



Most unmarried mothers are forced to depend on inadequate social
security payments. This is because the fathers of these children have
decided to neglect their ...
